stream_context.summary: Kaze focused on designing the boss fight for Raphael the Raven in Course 13. This involved extensive brainstorming of the fight's mechanics and phases, modeling the tower arena, creating a nest asset, and importing and configuring the level's music track from the composer, Badub.

development_findings.summary: Kaze adheres to a development principle of implementing features on a local 'actor level' rather than making universal changes to the game engine's core physics, like gravity. This led him to reject a 'hollow moon' boss fight concept.
development_findings.quote: The thing is, okay, here's my concern. That we need to make sure that the things we add can be done entirely on an actor level. And to do the hollow moon properly, we would need to make a change to how gravity works like universally, which I don't want.

development_findings.summary: The game will feature approximately 180 Stars and 75 Yoshi Coins (5 per level across 15 levels), with Kaze noting the content is comparable to or greater than Mario Odyssey's.
The game's music uses two formats: about 80-90% is a MIDI-like format called M64, while the rest is a streamed format that is used sparingly due to its large file size.
Kaze has encountered a bug in the Fast64 tool where using 'material bleeding' can cause fog to remain enabled in-game even when it's turned off in Blender.
A rideable Yoshi is not yet implemented but is a possibility for later, as Kaze states he has created a good implementation for it in the past.
Kaze is considering releasing a demo that would only feature the first course of the game.
The vertical camera controls were intentionally made not to snap to positions to improve the experience for players using a GameCube controller's C-stick, preventing accidental camera shifts.
development_findings.quote: A lot of people play Mario 64 with a Gamecube controller and the C-Stick instead of a C-Button. And with the stick it's really easy to accidentally hit up and down. So just as a way to combat that, we remove that feature.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes the core design principle of Mario 64 is freedom of movement and player expression, not inherent difficulty. He feels players can create their own challenges through skillful play rather than needing the game to force it on them.
context_findings.quote: I am convinced people that need Mario 64 to be difficult just do not understand the point of Mario 64. The point is that you're free. It's all freedom. If you want the game to be more difficult and do more risky jumps, just go for it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze intentionally avoids looking at the Nintendo Giga Leak, believing that using or even knowing about its contents is problematic and could lead to trouble.
context_findings.quote: I wanted nothing to do with that. Just because I think that even just knowing about things in the giga leak can get you in trouble. It's like the curse knowledge. You look at that and you just open Pandora's box.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses disdain for the trend of people entering programming solely for high salaries, viewing it as a bubble that was destined to burst.
context_findings.quote: I'm in this for money. I don't care about whether I'm fulfilled. I want money. That's how people treat programming for the longest time. And of course the bubble was going to burst.

context_findings.summary: Kaze and his wife, Zeina, recently had a baby. He mentions that Zeina has more work with the baby than he does, and jokes about not being able to lactate.
Kaze mentions having a recent, terrible knee injury that is making him cautious about doing squats, but he still maintains a workout routine including deadlifts and weighted pull-ups.

biobak.summary: Biobak contributes to gameplay concepts, not just graphics. Kaze references a video Biobak sent him with an idea for the Raphael the Raven boss fight.
biobak.quote: This is what he was thinking. That's so cool.

badub.summary: Kaze praises Badub's music, specifically highlighting his creativity. He imports a new track for the Ice Dungeon during the stream.
badub.quote: Badubb's music is great. The creativity he brings to the table is very, very sick.

badub.summary: The game's original soundtrack, largely composed by Badub, currently consists of 98 songs, which is more than Mario Odyssey.

zeina.summary: Zeina, Kaze's wife, is taking on the primary childcare responsibilities for their newborn baby.
zeina.quote: Of course, Zeina has a lot more work with it than I do. I guess I can't feed the baby, I do not have boobs.

key_stories.title: Designing the Raphael the Raven Boss Fight
key_stories.summary: Kaze and the team designed the Raphael the Raven boss fight, moving from initial concepts to a detailed multi-phase encounter. They navigated creative desires and technical limitations, rejecting a simple remake of the original fight in favor of a new concept involving planetary gravity, unique attack patterns, and a dramatic setting.
key_stories.challenge: The team needed to design a compelling 3D boss fight for Raphael the Raven that felt fresh and avoided being a simple rehash of the 2D boss fight from the original Yoshi's Island.
key_stories.process: Kaze brainstormed numerous ideas, including having the boss flip the level upside down. He considered and rejected a 'hollow moon' concept due to technical constraints (it would require universal gravity changes). He debated using the regular vs. an ice-themed raven, ultimately settling on a design that leverages the iconic moon setting in a new, 3D-centric way.
key_stories.outcome: A detailed, multi-phase boss fight concept was created. It involves Mario being launched to a moon, dodging stars in a free-fall sequence, fighting the raven on the moon's surface by using 'frozen cheese ninja stars', and a final phase back on the tower where the star hatches from an egg in a nest.
key_stories.key_quote: Wouldn't it really be good to just recycle the exact same boss fight that Yoshi's Island has though? Isn't that kind of lame? Doesn't that feel like a cheap callback?

key_stories.title: The Philosophy of Freedom vs. Difficulty
key_stories.summary: Kaze pushes back against the idea that Mario 64 hacks must be difficult. He explains and demonstrates that the original game's genius lies in its freedom, allowing players to create their own challenge through skillful play, a philosophy he is embedding into 'Return to Yoshi's Island'.
key_stories.challenge: Addressing the community expectation or desire for ROM hacks to be inherently difficult.
key_stories.process: After a chat comment, Kaze explained his philosophy on difficulty in Mario 64. He then launched the original game and demonstrated how a player can create their own difficulty by attempting risky and stylish jumps, proving that the game's freedom is its core strength.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze articulated a core design philosophy for the project: the game should provide a sandbox for expressive, freeform movement rather than a linear, punishing challenge. This principle guides the level design to favor player freedom over forced difficulty.
key_stories.key_quote: I am convinced people that need Mario 64 to be difficult just do not understand the point of Mario 64. The point is that you're free.

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions receiving a video from Biobak with a boss fight concept and regularly imports music from Badub. The collaboration appears effective but the process is not detailed.

open_questions.topic: Development Philosophy: Actor-Level vs. Universal Code Changes
open_questions.context: When brainstorming the boss fight, Kaze decided against a 'hollow moon' concept because it would require universal changes to the game's gravity code. He stated a preference for keeping new mechanics on an 'actor level'.
questions: You mentioned wanting to keep changes on an 'actor level' instead of making 'universal' engine changes. Can you elaborate on this development philosophy?
How has this principle of avoiding core engine changes shaped the design of the entire game?
Has there ever been a feature you desperately wanted to add but couldn't because it would violate this rule? What was it?

open_questions.topic: Collaboration with the Broader Modding Community
open_questions.context: Kaze mentions he needs to program the moon's gravity for the boss fight and plans to ask someone named 'Arthur' for his planetary gravity code.
questions: Who is Arthur and what is his relationship to the project?
How often do you collaborate with or use code from developers outside of the core team?
How does the broader ROM hacking community share knowledge and code, and how has that ecosystem influenced this project?

open_questions.topic: Ethics and Impact of the Nintendo Giga Leak
open_questions.context: Kaze stated he intentionally avoids the Nintendo Giga Leak, calling it 'cursed knowledge' and a 'Pandora's box' that could get him in trouble.
